problems.author: Thenura Wickramaratna
problems.question: What happens to atomic radius as you move across a period (left → right)?
problems.hint: Think about increasing nuclear charge pulling electrons in.
problems.detailed: As you go across a period, protons increase, pulling electrons closer so atomic radius decreases.

problems.author: Thenura Wickramaratna
problems.question: What trend does ionization energy follow across a period?
problems.hint: More protons → stronger hold on electrons.
problems.detailed: Ionization energy increases from left to right because atoms hold electrons more tightly due to increased positive charge in the nucleus.

problems.author: Thenura Wickramaratna
problems.question: How does electronegativity generally change going down a group?
problems.hint: More shells → electrons further away from nucleus.
problems.detailed: As you move down a group, electronegativity decreases because valence electrons are further from the nucleus and more shielded.

problems.author: Thenura Wickramaratna
problems.question: Which trend is true when moving down a group in the periodic table?
problems.detailed: Going down a group adds electron shells, which increases the atomic radius.

problems.author: Thenura Wickramaratna
problems.question: Which factor contributes to higher ionization energy across a period?
options: More valence electrons far from nucleus
problems.hint: More protons add stronger pull in the nucleus.
problems.detailed: Increased nuclear charge as you move across a period makes it harder to remove electrons, raising ionization energy.
